Module chav1961.purelib
Package chav1961.purelib.basic

Class CharUtils

java.lang.Object
chav1961.purelib.basic.CharUtils
public class CharUtils
extends java.lang.Object

This class contains implementation of the most-commonly-used char data parsing/printing functions in the system. It can be used to parse character representation of various content, convert the content to it's native form and make reversal converting to it's character representation. All the parsing methods in the class are oriented to direct parsing of the char arrays, not strings. It allow to avoid non-productive conversions from char array to String instance and revert string content to it's character array representation. This ability increases performance of character data processing, especially for Java 9 and newer. All methods in the class are thread-safe.

The class supports:

  • parsing of numerical data (integer, long, float, double) to convert it to their native representation and reversal converting to character arrays
  • escaping and un-escaping character array and string content (frequently used on XML, JSON, CSV format processing)
  • support Java enum and field representation parsing
  • support substitutions in the character and string content
  • a set of useful methods for the char content processing

Parsing and printing numerical content

Methods for parsing numerical content are:

  • parseInt(char[], int, int[], boolean), parseSignedInt(char[], int, int[], boolean), parseIntExtended(char[], int, int[], boolean) - parse character representation of integers and convert it to native integers
  • parseLong(char[], int, long[], boolean), parseSignedLong(char[], int, long[], boolean), parseLongExtended(char[], int, long[], boolean) - parse character representation of longs and convert it to native longs
  • parseFloat(char[], int, float[], boolean), parseSignedFloat(char[], int, float[], boolean) - parse character representation of floats and convert it to native floats
  • parseDouble(char[], int, double[], boolean), parseSignedDouble(char[], int, double[], boolean) - parse character representation of doubles and convert it to native doubles
  • parseNumber(char[], int, long[], int, boolean) - parse character representation of numbers, auto-detected minimal type to store parsed value, and convert parsed value to the type detected

All these methods accept source data array and starting position from it to parse, and returns the position in the source array after parsing. This returned value can then be used in the subsequent calls as starting position. Any parsed object are returned from the methods thru the arrays of appropriative data. This technique emulates call-by-reference mode for the method parameters, for example:

final char[] source = "1234 1234".toCharArray();
final int[] value1 = new int[1], value2 = new int[1];
final int endPos1 = CharsUtil.parseInt(source,0,value1,false); // endPos1 = 4, value1[0] = 1234
final int endPos2 = CharsUtil.parseInt(source,endPos1+1,value2,false); // endPos2 = 9, value2[0] = 5678

Class CharUtils also contains method validateNumber(char[], int, int, boolean) to check character content is a valid number representation.

Methods for printing numerical content are:

  • printLong(char[], int, long, boolean) - convert native long to it's character representation
  • printDouble(char[], int, double, boolean) - convert native double to it's character representation

All the printing methods in the class are oriented to direct filling of the char arrays. Every method accepts target data array and the free starting position to fill result, and returns the new free position in the array. Negative returned value means that the target array is too small to keep result. It absolute value exactly reflect new free position in the target array and can be used to expand target array to required size

All the methods can throw SyntaxException on parsing errors, and PrintingException on printing.

Escaping and un-escaping content

Methods to escaping and un-escaping are used to convert internal representation of chars, char arrays and strings to it's external representation form (for example, to use inside JSON double-quoted values). Methods to escape are:

  • symbolNeedsEscaping(char, boolean), isSymbolPrintable(char) and howManyEscapedCharsOccupies(char, boolean) - methods to check weather symbol requires escaping for external representation and how many chars it's external representation occupies
  • parseEscapedChar(char[], int, char[]), parseStringExtended(char[], int, char, Appendable) and parseStringExtended(char[], int, char, Appendable) - methods to parse escaped representation of the char content to it's native form
  • printEscapedChar(char[], int, char, boolean, boolean), printEscapedCharArray(char[], int, char[], boolean, boolean), printEscapedCharArray(char[], int, char[], int, int, boolean, boolean) and printEscapedString(char[], int, String, boolean, boolean) - methods to convert internal representation of character or string content to it's external escaped form
  • escapeStringContent(String) and unescapeStringContent(String) - methods to convert string content to and from it's internal representation to escaped external one

The class CharUtils also contains parseUnescapedString(char[], int, char, boolean, int[]) method to parse ordinal string content.

All the methods can throw SyntaxException on parsing errors, and PrintingException on printing.

Java enum and fields processing

Enum and fields processing can be used to parse and print enumeration values and field names in the char content. Methods to parse and print enumerations and fields are:

  • parseEnum(char[], int, Class, Enum[]) - method to parse enumeration constants
  • parseName(char[], int, int[]) and parseNameExtended(char[], int, int[], char...)- method to parse field names

All the methods can throw SyntaxException on parsing errors.

Substitutions support

Substitutions is a well-known mechanism for automatic replacement of keys in the character/string content with their current values. Keys in the CharUtils class are any sequences in the string content similar "...${key}...". To make substitution for it, one of the substitution interfaces can be used. The complete list of substitution interfaces in the class is:

  • CharUtils.SubstitutionSource - interface to support String->String replacement
  • CharUtils.CharSubstitutionSource - - interface to support char[]->char[] replacement

Methods to make substitutions are:

  • substitute(String, String, SubstitutionSource) - method to process string substitutions
  • substitute(String, char[], int, int, CharSubstitutionSource) - method to process char array substitutions

All the methods can throw SyntaxException on parsing errors.

Useful methods

Useful methods are:

  • a set of split(String, char) methods to split char/string content by divizors. Differ to String.split(String) method, they don't use regular expressions
  • a set of join(char[], char[]...) methods to join char/string content by divizors. Differ to String.join(CharSequence, CharSequence...) method, they use more effective implementation
  • a set of like(char[], char[], int) methods to implement SQL LIKE clause functionality. They don't use regular expressions
  • a set of compare(char[], int, char[], int, int) methods for character array comparison
  • extract(char[], int, Object[], Object...) and tryExtract(char[], int, Object...) methods for simplest parsers. They don't use regular expressions
  • terminateAndConvert2CharArray(String, char) method for a special functionality - terminate string representation with the given char and convert result to char array (frequently uses in parsers)

Many of the methods can throw SyntaxException on parsing errors.

Since:
0.0.1
Author:
Alexander Chernomyrdin aka chav1961
See Also:
JUnit tests
LastUpdate:

    • parseInt

      public static int parseInt​(char[] source, int from, int[] result, boolean checkOverflow) throws SyntaxException

      Extract unsigned integer value from the current position of the source data

      Parameters:
      source - source data contains character representation of the integer value
      from - starting position in the source data
      result - array (at least new int[1]) to store parsed value
      checkOverflow - need check overflow when parsing data
      Returns:
      position of the first char in the source after successful parsing of the current integer
      Throws:
      SyntaxException - if any parsing errors ware detected
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any argument errors ware detected
      LastUpdate:
      0.0.3

    • parseNumber

      public static int parseNumber​(char[] source, int from, long[] result, int preferences, boolean checkOverflow) throws SyntaxException

      Extract unsigned numeric value from the current position of the source data. This method uses a preferrable parameter to define data type you wish to get. Available preferences are described by PREF_INT, PREF_LONG, PREF_DOUBLE and PREF_ANY constants. This method always attempts to 'minimize' data type for parsed value (if value is greater than maximal integer, represents data as long, and if value is greater than maximal long, represents it as double).

      Parameters:
      source - source data contains character representation of the integer value
      from - starting position in the source data.
      result - array (new long[2]) to store parsed value. The first element contains parsed value, the second - current data type of the value (PREF_INT, PREF_LONG or PREF_DOUBLE). If the data type is PREF_DOUBLE, you need call Double.longBitsToDouble(long) method to convert the first element of array to double value
      preferences - available data types you wish to get
      checkOverflow - need check overflow when parsing data
      Returns:
      position of the first char in the source after successful parsing of the current integer
      Throws:
      SyntaxException - if any parsing errors ware detected
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any argument errors ware detected
      Since:
      0.0.1
      LastUpdate:
      0.0.3

    • validateNumber

      public static int validateNumber​(char[] source, int from, int preferences, boolean checkOverflow)

      Validate syntax of number value

      Parameters:
      source - content to validate number
      from - start position to parse number
      preferences - available data types you wish to get (see parseNumber(char[], int, long[], int, boolean))
      checkOverflow - check number overflow
      Returns:
      number of chars really parsed. Negative value means invalid value. It's absolute value marks the first invalid char location - 1.
      Since:
      0.0.3

    • symbolNeedsEscaping

      public static boolean symbolNeedsEscaping​(char symbol, boolean strongEscaping)

      Test weather the given char needs escaping in the external representation

      Parameters:
      symbol - symbol to test
      strongEscaping - true means mandatory escaping for all chars greater than 0xFF. False requires more smart analysis.
      Returns:
      true if the char need escaping

      Parameters:
      symbol - symbol to test
      Returns:
      true if the char need escaping

      LastUpdate:

    • parseUnescapedString

      public static int parseUnescapedString​(char[] source, int from, char terminal, boolean checkEscaping, int[] result)

      Parse unescaped string. This method defines location of the string was bound with the paired quotas (for example "before 'my string' after"). This method not supports any escape sequences inside the string. To process it, use #parseString(char[], int, char, StringBuilder) method

      Parameters:
      source - source data contains character representation of the string value
      from - starting position in the source data. Starting position need points not to quota mark, but the first character in the string (see JUnit tests)
      terminal - quota mark to use for the string binding (usually (") or ('))
      checkEscaping - test presence of any escaping. If true, negative returned value from the method marks about it
      result - array (new int[2]) to store start and end position of the detected string
      Returns:
      position of the first char in the source after successful parsing of the current string. Will be negative if checkEscaping=true and any escape sequence in the string will be detected. It can be used for optimization purposes to avoid rare escaping processing
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any parsing errors ware detected
      LastUpdate:
      0.0.4

    • parseString

      public static int parseString​(char[] source, int from, char terminal, java.lang.Appendable result)

      Parse escaped string. DIffer to parseUnescapedString(char[], int, char, boolean, int[]) correctly process the escape sequences. Available escape sequences are oriented to the sequences used in the JSON string (see JSON description RFC)

      Parameters:
      source - source data contains character representation of the string value
      from - starting position in the source data. Starting position need points not to quota mark, but the first character in the string (see JUnit tests)
      terminal - quota mark to use for the string binding (usually (") or ('))
      result - string builder to store parsed string
      Returns:
      position of the first char in the source after successful parsing of the current string
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any parsing errors ware detected
      LastUpdate:
      0.0.4

    • parseStringExtended

      public static int parseStringExtended​(char[] source, int from, char terminal, java.lang.Appendable result)

      Parse escaped string. DIffer to #parseString(char[], int, char, StringBuilder) also correctly process advanced escape sequences (\0NNN and \0xNNN).

      Parameters:
      source - source data contains character representation of the string value
      from - starting position in the source data. Starting position need points not to quota mark, but the first character in the string (see JUnit tests)
      terminal - quota mark to use for the string binding (usually (") or ('))
      result - string builder to store parsed string
      Returns:
      position of the first char in the source after successful parsing of the current string
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any parsing errors ware detected
      LastUpdate:
      0.0.4

    • parseEnum

      public static <T extends java.lang.Enum<?>> int parseEnum​(char[] source, int from, java.lang.Class<T> clazz, T[] result)

      Parse enumeration constants from the source

      Type Parameters:
      T - enumeration type
      Parameters:
      source - source data contains character representation of the string value
      from - starting position in the source data.
      clazz - enumeration class awaited for the constant
      result - array (new Enum[1]) to store parsed enumeration constant
      Returns:
      position of the first char in the source after successful parsing of the enumeration constant
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any parsing errors ware detected

    • tryExtract

      public static int tryExtract​(char[] source, int from, java.lang.Object... lexemas) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException, SyntaxException

      Try to extract content from input character array with lexemas. Returns non-negative number if extraction was successful. Lexemas can be:

      • single character - marks character 'as-is' in the input array
      • string - marks sequence of characters in the input array
      • CharUtils.ArgumentType - marks kind of predefined lexema in the input array
      Parameters:
      source - source array to try extraction from
      from - start position to extract content from
      lexemas - lexemas list to try extract
      Returns:
      non-negative first position after parsed piece of characters in the input array or (negative position-1) in the input array where parsing failed
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - on any invalid parameters
      SyntaxException - on any syntax error in the content
      Since:
      0.0.3
      LastUpdate:
      0.0.4

    • extract

      public static int extract​(char[] source, int from, java.lang.Object[] result, java.lang.Object... lexemas) throws SyntaxException

      Extract content from input character array according to lexemas list. Failed extraction produces SyntaxException.

      Parameters:
      source - source array to extraction from
      from - start position to extract content from
      result - array to store extracted content to. It's capacity must be enough to receive all the content extracted
      lexemas - lexemas list to extract. See tryExtract(char[], int, Object...) for details
      Returns:
      first position after parsed piece of characters in the input array
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - on any invalid parameters
      SyntaxException - on any syntax error in the content
      Since:
      0.0.3

    • like

      public static int like​(char[] source, char[] template, int from) throws java.lang.NullPointerException, java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      Performs 'like' operation in char arrays (see SQL language syntax)

      Parameters:
      source - source array to test
      template - template to test. Wild cards of the template are (*) - any sequence, (?) - exactly one char
      from - start testing like in the source
      Returns:
      length 'liked' if resolved, or any negative value if doesn't like
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - if source or template are null
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if from position out of range
      Since:
      0.0.3

    • like

      public static int like​(char[] source, char[] template, int from, int to) throws java.lang.NullPointerException, java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      Performs 'like' operation in char arrays (see SQL language syntax)

      Parameters:
      source - source array to test
      template - template to test. Wild cards of the template are (*) - any sequence, (?) - exactly one char
      from - start testing like in the source
      to - end testing like in the source
      Returns:
      length 'liked' if resolved, or any negative value if doesn't like
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - when any char array references are null
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - when any errors in the arguments
      Since:
      0.0.3

    • printLong

      public static int printLong​(char[] content, int from, long value, boolean reallyFill) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      Print long number to the char array

      Parameters:
      content - char array to fill with long
      from - start position in the char array to fill
      value - long value to fill to content
      reallyFill - weather really fill content. When false, only total filled size will be calculated
      Returns:
      new from position to continue filling content. Negative value marks that content is too short to keep value. It's absolute value exactly marks new from position to continue filling
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any argument errors ware detected

    • printDouble

      Returns:

      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any argument errors ware detected

    • printEscapedChar

      public static int printEscapedChar​(char[] content, int from, char value, boolean reallyFill, boolean strongEscaping) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      Print char to char array with escaping it if need

      Parameters:
      content - char array to fill with long
      from - start position in the char array to fill
      value - char value to fill to content
      reallyFill - weather really fill content. When false, only total filled size will be calculated
      strongEscaping - true strongly escapes all chars > 0xFF. False makes smart analyze
      Returns:
      new from position to continue filling content. Negative value marks that content is too short to keep value.
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - on any argument errors
      Since:
      0.0.2

      Print string to the char array with escaping if need. String terminators will not be printed, so you must print it yourself

      Parameters:
      content - char array to fill with long
      from - start position in the char array to fill
      value - char array value to fill to content
      charFrom - start position inside char array to fill from
      charTo - end position inside char array to fill from
      reallyFill - weather really fill content. When false, only total filled size will be calculated
      strongEscaping - true strongly escapes all chars > 0xFF. False makes smart analyze
      Returns:
      new from position to continue filling content. Negative value marks that content is too short to keep value.
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - on any argument errors

    • substitute

      public static java.lang.String substitute​(java.lang.String key, java.lang.String value, CharUtils.SubstitutionSource source) throws java.lang.NullPointerException, java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      Substitute string content. Seeks the ${<key_to_substitute>} sequence inside string value and substitute it with the key_to_substitute value. This value will be got by calling CharUtils.SubstitutionSource.getValue(String) method.

      Parameters:
      key - optional key to identify string value. Will be used in the exceptions if will be thrown
      value - value for substitution.
      source - interface to get values for keys detected
      Returns:
      value with substituted keys
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - when any parameters is null
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - when any problems during substitution were detected
      Since:
      0.0.2

    • substitute

      public static char[] substitute​(java.lang.String key, char[] value, int from, int length, CharUtils.CharSubstitutionSource source) throws java.lang.NullPointerException, java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      Substitute string content. Seeks the ${<key_to_substitute>} sequence inside string value and substitute it with the key_to_substitute value. This value will be got by calling CharUtils.SubstitutionSource.getValue(String) method.

      Parameters:
      key - optional key to identify string value. Will be used in the exceptions if will be thrown
      value - char array for substitution.
      from - start position in the char array to process substitution
      length - length of the content portion to process
      source - interface to get values for keys detected
      Returns:
      value with substituted keys
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - when any parameters is null
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - when any problems during substitution were detected
      Since:
      0.0.2

    • split

      public static java.lang.String[] split​(java.lang.String source, char splitter) throws java.lang.NullPointerException

      Split string into string arrays. Against String.split(String) doesn't use regular expressions

      Parameters:
      source - string to split
      splitter - splitter char
      Returns:
      string array with splitter string. Always contains at least one element
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - when source string is null
      Since:
      0.0.2

    • split

      public static java.lang.String[] split​(java.lang.String source, char splitter, boolean removeCornerEmpty, boolean removeTotalEmpty) throws java.lang.NullPointerException

      Split string into string arrays. Against String.split(String) doesn't use regular expressions

      Parameters:
      source - string to split
      splitter - splitter char
      removeCornerEmpty - remove corner elements from result, if they are empty
      removeTotalEmpty - remove all empty elements from result
      Returns:
      string array with splitter string. Always contains at least one element
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - when source string is null
      Since:
      0.0.4

    • split

      public static int split​(java.lang.String source, char splitter, java.lang.String[] target) throws java.lang.NullPointerException

      Split string into string arrays. Against String.split(String) doesn't use regular expressions

      Parameters:
      source - string to split
      splitter - splitter char
      target - target array to receive strings splitted
      Returns:
      non-negative number - number of pieces of the splitted string, negative number - -(number of pieces of the splitted string + 1). Negative number means that target array is too small to receive content (nothing will be filled in this case)
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - when either source or target parameter is null
      Since:
      0.0.2

      Returns:
      non-negative number - number of pieces of the splitted string, negative number - -(number of pieces of the splitted string + 1). Negative number means that target array is too small to receive content (nothing will be filled in this case)
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - when either source or target parameter is null

      to - end index inside char array to make sequence
      Returns:
      wrapper created. Can't be null
